Entries.default: "Thank you. Just - thank you. For everything."
"Duskspeaker, Duskspeaker! I'd like to speak, if you've a moment."
"You are the Duskspeaker, nae?" The willowy Glamfellen searches you desperately.
With a sigh, Brythe examines her boots.
"Was there something else you wanted to know?"
"Farewell."
"What do you do here at Harbingers' Watch?"
"Whatever needs doing, odds and ends and such."
"There's another group up top, on top of the ice, I mean, high above the Watch. They attack anyone they see, us included."
"They make it very difficult to, well, to get to Rymrgand's temple. Among other things."
"Where did these pilgrims come from?"
"They're from the Land, as well. They came here a few decades before we did, on much the same mission. When none returned, we thought them all dead."
"Why are they so hostile?"
"Wael only knows! They seem to think they're protecting something. Like the Floe is sacred."
"I'll see what I can do about them."
"I promise nothing."
A huge smile splits the elf's face as she clasps her hands together.
"I - I understand." She nods, attention falling to the floor.
"The pilgrims keep camp in the ruins atop the ice wall. High Harbinger Vatnir can explain how to get up there. If he hasn't already."
"Hájo, again! I hope the pilgrims have not been too much trouble to you."
"I killed the pilgrims on the outcrop above."

"Here. I've not much coin, but you've done as I've asked, so it's yours."

She pushes a fat pouch of Vailian coinage into your hands.
"When you did your bloody work atop the Floe, did you see a woman, about thirty winters my senior, with skin matching mine and hair the color of butter?"
"I already killed them."
"No, but I wasn't looking. I would have, if I'd known to."
"If you sought someone, you should have told me as much. If she's dead, that's on your soul."
"I don't remember. I can go check the corpses if you'd like."
"That's - sure, that makes sense. I mean, she probably wasn't there. I just asked because, well. Because."
"Gods, I know it. Don't you think I know that?" She trembles, her hands curled into fists.
With a sigh that sends a shudder through her small body, Brythe shakes her head.
"Still, I suppose it's a good thing for the Watch, you ending the pilgrim threat."
"I am."
"So people keep telling me."
"You see any other unfamiliar faces?"
"I'm nobody's holy man."
"You've a point there, certainly." She nods rapidly.
"It's all a bit much, isn't it, the end of the world rubbish?" She chuckles.
"I could - well, we all could, actually - we could really use your aid." Her fingers play at one of her braids.
"The world will end, child. Everything does. Yet I appreciate your... skepticism."
"Not rubbish, I mean, certainly, just, it's all so..." She blinks rapidly at Vatnir.
"Just tell the Duskspeaker what you want of him, Brythe." Vatnir rests a bandaged hand upon Brythe's shoulder. The elf nods, neither cringing nor shying away.
Entries.female: "Just tell the Duskspeaker what you want of her, Brythe." Vatnir rests a bandaged hand upon Brythe's shoulder. The elf nods, neither cringing nor shying away.

Entries.default: Brythe's eyes widen as she takes in Ydwin. Biting her lip, she nods.
"I promise nothing."
"I - I understand." She nods, attention falling to the floor.
"The pilgrims keep camp in the ruins atop the ice wall. High Harbinger Vatnir can explain how to get up there. If he hasn't already."
"Who exactly are these other people?"
"Another group of Rymrgand's worshippers. We call them the lost pilgrims."
"We're striding into a conflict between religious fanatics? Fantastic."
"Finding the pilgrims was part of the reason we came here. Unfortunately, they didn't want to be found."
"Nyvardir thinks they've all gone a bit mad out here, all alone. Or that something in the ice is rotting their minds."
"Ridiculous."

"Apologies, High Harbinger."

A faint blush flowers across Brythe's grayish cheeks.
"Finally good news. You've no idea how rare a thing that is!"
"You seem very young to be out here."
She snorts, crossing her arms and squaring her shoulders.
"I may be no Valbrendhür, but I've winters enough for certain." She squares her shoulders as if in challenge.
"I'll have you know I've nearly sixty winters behind me! More than you, I'd reckon!"

"I've been here a solid ten winters already. Came looking for... well, something I've not found yet."
 
She glances away.
"Strictly, uh, speaking in a religious sense."
Her averted glance and stuttered words suggest that she's not sharing the entire truth.
"It seems like there's something you're not telling me."
Her eyes widen in surprise before nearly closing with her wince.
"Cer - certainly. And I'll be entirely happy to discuss it... later. Elsewhere, ja?"
"The whole community works together to survive. I hunt, I weave, I roast a delicious ysae."
"You - you killed them? All of them?" Her mouth hangs open.
"They didn't leave me much of a choice."
"Every last elf."
"Isn't that what you wanted?"
"They're no longer a threat."

"I wanted them - I wanted them dealt with. Surely there were..."

She shakes her head.

"Foolish Brythe. You asked the Duskspeaker. What did you expect?"

She rubs her forehead.
"So many..." Her face falls into her waiting palms.
"What's bothering you, Brythe? Perhaps I can help."
"Did I do something wrong?"
"Do you have further work for me?"
[Leave] "Thanks."

"No, no. No."

She shakes her head.

"I..."

Her mouth twists, first into a frown, then a grimace. Finally her gray lips pull into a tight line.
"No, not more work. But perhaps..." She frowns.
"Out with it, lass." Serafen gently touches Brythe's arm.
"Family, I take it?"
"My sister, Ehrys." Her nod is but a small movement.
"You'd a sister among the pilgrims and kept that from us?"

"We could've used that! Established communication. Worked out some agreement with them!"

Spittle flies from the godlike's ragged mouth.
"Ease up on her, Vatnir."
"He's right. You could've helped a lot of people. And saved me a lot of killing."
[Say nothing.]
He slowly shakes his head at her in disappointment.
She shrinks beneath your words, hands kneading one another, head bowed.
"I'm... I'm so sorry."

Vatnir snorts, crosses his arm, and turns away.

Brythe turns a faint smile on you.
"Still, I would know. Did you see her?"
"Your sister came with the pilgrims?"
"It's... it's why I'm here. Did you see her?"
"Fejin haemkamür, Duskspeaker."
[Walk away.]
"Was there something else you wanted to know?"
"No, no. I can pick through corpses myself. I can manage that much."
"Ehrys - my sister - she was always, well, she believed, truly believed, in a way that I never have."
"Not that the gods were real. Obviously Rymrgand exists, but that doesn’t mean we've taken the right lessons from him. Or interpreted them correctly."
"How was it you knew one of the pilgrims?"
"I'll keep an eye out for any signs of her."
"Damn right it was."
"How did your sister come to be a pilgrim?"
"I appreciate that."
"I said as much, didn't I?"

"Ehrys was always surer. She's smart, incredibly smart, always very interested in souls and machines and the like. But she was also very, very... convinced."

Hugging herself, she exhales a ragged breath.
"I've wasted enough of your time. I doubt Ehrys still alive after all this time. But it would have been nice to have known. For certain."

"Dhakklát, Duskspeaker. And farewell."

She proffers a weak smile and turns away.
Carmine eyes narrowed in thought, Ydwin frowns at the younger Glamfellen.
"What is it?"
"Think we can't trust her?"
[Ignore her and leave.]
She turns a raised eyebrow on you, lips twisting into a slight smirk.
"No, it's not that."
"That one reminds me of myself at her age. Not quite clever enough to realize how clever she is."
"Nor half clever enough to realize how much cleverer she'll need to be."
"Shall we carry on, Duskspeaker?"
<link="neutralvalue://Ordhjóma: We always do.">"Vith jerüm dháth eldtaf."</link>
"Let's."
[Nod silently.]
[Say nothing.]
With a small bow, Ydwin nods.
She chuckles quietly.
"I found your sister."
"Do you know anything of the temple within the Floe or the Vytmádh within?"
"Have you found any sign of your sister?"
[Leave] "Not right now."
"Nae, I've found none at all." She shakes her head.
"I don't, nae."
"Vatnir might've been able to tell you more on that."
"If anyone can tell you about that, it'd be High Harbinger Vatnir."
"You did? Where is she? Is she - is she alive?"
"I'm sorry. She's not."
"I'm sorry. She didn't make it."
"She asked me to transfer her soul into a construct. So I did."
"I killed her."
"I always knew that was a possibility. But to have hope shattered... What became of her?"
"She did what? And you let her? I must - I have to go see her!" She blinks rapidly, still processing the revelation.
"You did what? Wh - why?"
"Based on her wounds, I'd say she made an enemy of a bear."
"She attempted to enter the Beyond through the Vytmádh. It destroyed her utterly."
"She'd succumbed to the madness of the White Void."
"She left me little choice. It was her or me."
"Killing crazy cultists is what I do."

"Someone should do the same to you, you sack of skyt!"

She spits on the ground and spins on her heels from you.

"I guess - I guess I understand. Thank you for finding her. Even if."

Eyes glistening, she shakes her head and turns away.
"Go then. She's waiting for you."
"That might not be the best idea."
"Ehrys said she hoped you'd never see her like that."
"She was a pilgrim, and now she's a temple guardian. She'll almost certainly attack you if you find her."
[Shrug.]
"I have to find her! Thank you, Duskspeaker! Thank you for everything!"

"Oh. Okay. I understand. Thank you for finding her. And helping her, I suppose."

She deflates with a sigh and, rubbing her eye with the ball of one hand, turns away.
"Duskspeaker! Ehrys returned to us!"
"Everyone else wanted to fill her with arrows, but I managed to talk them down."
"Still... she's not quite the elf I remember. I wonder what happened out there." She glances at Ehrys and rubs her own upper arms.
"It's strange to think of her out there, standing vigil forever."
"Go ruin someone else's life."
"It's better you don't know."
"She attempted to transfer her soul into a construct. She failed."
